member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Archives.AbstractArchive`2.ExtractAllEntries
member.summary:
Use this method to extract all entries in an archive in order. This is primarily for SOLID Rar Archives or 7Zip Archives as they need to be extracted sequentially for the best performance.
This method will load all entry information from the archive.
WARNING: this will reuse the underlying stream for the archive. Errors may occur if this is used at the same time as other extraction methods on this instance.

member.name: P:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.DeflateStream.BufferSize
member.summary: The size of the working buffer for the compression codec.

remarks.para: The working buffer is used for all stream operations. The default size is 1024 bytes. The minimum size is 128 bytes. You may get better performance with a larger buffer. Then again, you might not. You would have to test it.
Set this before the first call to Read() or Write() on the stream. If you try to set it afterwards, it will throw.

member.summary: The ZLIB strategy to be used during compression.
member.remarks: By tweaking this parameter, you may be able to optimize the compression for data with particular characteristics.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.DeflateStream.Read(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Read data from the stream.

remarks.para: If you wish to use the DeflateStream to compress data while reading, you can create a DeflateStream with CompressionMode.Compress, providing an uncompressed data stream. Then call Read() on that DeflateStream, and the data read will be compressed as you read. If you wish to use the DeflateStream to decompress data while reading, you can create a DeflateStream with CompressionMode.Decompress, providing a readable compressed data stream. Then call Read() on that DeflateStream, and the data read will be decompressed as you read.
A DeflateStream can be used for Read() or Write(), but not both.

member.param: The buffer into which the read data should be placed.
the offset within that data array to put the first byte read.
the number of bytes to read.
member.returns: the number of bytes actually read

this is irrelevant, since it will always throw!

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.DeflateStream.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Write data to the stream.

remarks.para: If you wish to use the DeflateStream to compress data while writing, you can create a DeflateStream with CompressionMode.Compress, and a writable output stream. Then call Write() on that DeflateStream, providing uncompressed data as input. The data sent to the output stream will be the compressed form of the data written. If you wish to use the DeflateStream to decompress data while writing, you can create a DeflateStream with CompressionMode.Decompress, and a writable output stream. Then call Write() on that stream, providing previously compressed data. The data sent to the output stream will be the decompressed form of the data written.
A DeflateStream can be used for Read() or Write(), but not both.

member.param: The buffer holding data to write to the stream.
the offset within that data array to find the first byte to write.
the number of bytes to write.

member.name: T:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.FlushType
member.summary: Describes how to flush the current deflate operation.
member.remarks: The different FlushType values are useful when using a Deflate in a streaming application.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.FlushType.None
member.summary: No flush at all.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.FlushType.Partial
member.summary: Closes the current block, but doesn't flush it to the output. Used internally only in hypothetical scenarios. This was supposed to be removed by Zlib, but it is still in use in some edge cases.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.FlushType.Sync
member.summary: Use this during compression to specify that all pending output should be flushed to the output buffer and the output should be aligned on a byte boundary. You might use this in a streaming communication scenario, so that the decompressor can get all input data available so far. When using this with a ZlibCodec, AvailableBytesIn will be zero after the call if enough output space has been provided before the call. Flushing will degrade compression and so it should be used only when necessary.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.FlushType.Full
member.summary: Use this during compression to specify that all output should be flushed, as with FlushType.Sync, but also, the compression state should be reset so that decompression can restart from this point if previous compressed data has been damaged or if random access is desired. Using FlushType.Full too often can significantly degrade the compression.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.FlushType.Finish
member.summary: Signals the end of the compression/decompression stream.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.GZipStream.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Write data to the stream.

remarks.para: If you wish to use the GZipStream to compress data while writing, you can create a GZipStream with CompressionMode.Compress, and a writable output stream. Then call Write() on that GZipStream, providing uncompressed data as input. The data sent to the output stream will be the compressed form of the data written.
A GZipStream can be used for Read() or Write(), but not both. Writing implies compression. Reading implies decompression.

member.param: The buffer holding data to write to the stream.
the offset within that data array to find the first byte to write.
the number of bytes to write.

member.name: T:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionLevel
member.summary: The compression level to be used when using a DeflateStream or ZlibStream with CompressionMode.Compress.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionLevel.None
member.summary: None means that the data will be simply stored, with no change at all. If you are producing ZIPs for use on Mac OSX, be aware that archives produced with CompressionLevel.None cannot be opened with the default zip reader. Use a different CompressionLevel.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionLevel.Level0
member.summary: Same as None.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionLevel.BestSpeed
member.summary: The fastest but least effective compression.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionLevel.Level1
member.summary: A synonym for BestSpeed.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionLevel.Level2
member.summary: A little slower, but better, than level 1.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionLevel.Level3
member.summary: A little slower, but better, than level 2.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionLevel.Level4
member.summary: A little slower, but better, than level 3.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionLevel.Level5
member.summary: A little slower than level 4, but with better compression.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionLevel.Default
member.summary: The default compression level, with a good balance of speed and compression efficiency.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionLevel.Level6
member.summary: A synonym for Default.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionLevel.Level7
member.summary: Pretty good compression!

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionLevel.Level8
member.summary: Better compression than Level7!

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionLevel.BestCompression
member.summary: The "best" compression, where best means greatest reduction in size of the input data stream. This is also the slowest compression.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionLevel.Level9
member.summary: A synonym for BestCompression.

member.name: T:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionStrategy
member.summary: Describes options for how the compression algorithm is executed. Different strategies work better on different sorts of data. The strategy parameter can affect the compression ratio and the speed of compression but not the correctness of the compresssion.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionStrategy.Default
member.summary: The default strategy is probably the best for normal data.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionStrategy.Filtered
member.summary: The Filtered strategy is intended to be used most effectively with data produced by a filter or predictor. By this definition, filtered data consists mostly of small values with a somewhat random distribution. In this case, the compression algorithm is tuned to compress them better. The effect of Filtered is to force more Huffman coding and less string matching; it is a half-step between Default and HuffmanOnly.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.CompressionStrategy.HuffmanOnly
member.summary: Using HuffmanOnly will force the compressor to do Huffman encoding only, with no string matching.

member.name: T:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.Adler
member.summary: Computes an Adler-32 checksum.
member.remarks: The Adler checksum is similar to a CRC checksum, but faster to compute, though less reliable. It is used in producing RFC1950 compressed streams. The Adler checksum is a required part of the "ZLIB" standard. Applications will almost never need to use this class directly.

member.name: T:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec
member.summary: Encoder and Decoder for ZLIB and DEFLATE (IETF RFC1950 and RFC1951).
member.remarks: This class compresses and decompresses data according to the Deflate algorithm and optionally, the ZLIB format, as documented in RFC 1950 - ZLIB and RFC 1951 - DEFLATE.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.InputBuffer
member.summary: The buffer from which data is taken.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.NextIn
member.summary: An index into the InputBuffer array, indicating where to start reading.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.AvailableBytesIn
member.summary: The number of bytes available in the InputBuffer, starting at NextIn.
member.remarks: Generally you should set this to InputBuffer.Length before the first Inflate() or Deflate() call. The class will update this number as calls to Inflate/Deflate are made.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.TotalBytesIn
member.summary: Total number of bytes read so far, through all calls to Inflate()/Deflate().

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.OutputBuffer
member.summary: Buffer to store output data.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.NextOut
member.summary: An index into the OutputBuffer array, indicating where to start writing.

member.summary: The number of bytes available in the OutputBuffer, starting at NextOut.
member.remarks: Generally you should set this to OutputBuffer.Length before the first Inflate() or Deflate() call. The class will update this number as calls to Inflate/Deflate are made.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.TotalBytesOut
member.summary: Total number of bytes written to the output so far, through all calls to Inflate()/Deflate().

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.Message
member.summary: used for diagnostics, when something goes wrong!

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.CompressLevel
member.summary: The compression level to use in this codec. Useful only in compression mode.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.WindowBits
member.summary: The number of Window Bits to use.
member.remarks: This gauges the size of the sliding window, and hence the compression effectiveness as well as memory consumption. It's best to just leave this setting alone if you don't know what it is. The maximum value is 15 bits, which implies a 32k window.

member.name: F:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.Strategy
member.summary: The compression strategy to use.
member.remarks: This is only effective in compression. The theory offered by ZLIB is that different strategies could potentially produce significant differences in compression behavior for different data sets. Unfortunately I don't have any good recommendations for how to set it differently. When I tested changing the strategy I got minimally different compression performance. It's best to leave this property alone if you don't have a good feel for it. Or, you may want to produce a test harness that runs through the different strategy options and evaluates them on different file types. If you do that, let me know your results.

member.name: P:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.Adler32
member.summary: The Adler32 checksum on the data transferred through the codec so far. You probably don't need to look at this.

member.summary: Create a ZlibCodec.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.InitializeInflate
member.summary: Initialize the inflation state.
member.remarks: It is not necessary to call this before using the ZlibCodec to inflate data; It is implicitly called when you call the constructor.
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.InitializeInflate(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initialize the inflation state with an explicit flag to govern the handling of RFC1950 header bytes.
member.remarks: By default, the ZLIB header defined in RFC 1950 is expected. If you want to read a zlib stream you should specify true for expectRfc1950Header. If you have a deflate stream, you will want to specify false. It is only necessary to invoke this initializer explicitly if you want to specify false.
member.param: whether to expect an RFC1950 header byte pair when reading the stream of data to be inflated.
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.InitializeInflate(System.Int32)
member.summary: Initialize the ZlibCodec for inflation, with the specified number of window bits.
member.param: The number of window bits to use. If you need to ask what that is, then you shouldn't be calling this initializer.
member.returns: Z_OK if all goes well.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.InitializeInflate(System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initialize the inflation state with an explicit flag to govern the handling of RFC1950 header bytes.
member.remarks: If you want to read a zlib stream you should specify true for expectRfc1950Header. In this case, the library will expect to find a ZLIB header, as defined in RFC 1950, in the compressed stream. If you will be reading a DEFLATE or GZIP stream, which does not have such a header, you will want to specify false.
member.param: whether to expect an RFC1950 header byte pair when reading the stream of data to be inflated.
The number of window bits to use. If you need to ask what that is, then you shouldn't be calling this initializer.
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.remarks: You must have set InputBuffer and OutputBuffer, NextIn and NextOut, and AvailableBytesIn and AvailableBytesOut before calling this method.
member.param: The flush to use when inflating.
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibCodec.EndInflate
member.summary: Ends an inflation session.
member.remarks: Call this after successively calling Inflate(). This will cause all buffers to be flushed. After calling this you cannot call Inflate() without a intervening call to one of the InitializeInflate() overloads.
member.returns: Z_OK if everything goes well.

member.remarks: The codec will use the MAX window bits and the default level of compression.

whether to emit an initial RFC1950 byte pair in the compressed stream.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibStream.Read(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Read data from the stream.

remarks.para: If you wish to use the ZlibStream to compress data while reading, you can create a ZlibStream with CompressionMode.Compress, providing an uncompressed data stream. Then call Read() on that ZlibStream, and the data read will be compressed. If you wish to use the ZlibStream to decompress data while reading, you can create a ZlibStream with CompressionMode.Decompress, providing a readable compressed data stream. Then call Read() on that ZlibStream, and the data will be decompressed as it is read.
A ZlibStream can be used for Read() or Write(), but not both.

member.param: The buffer into which the read data should be placed.
the offset within that data array to put the first byte read.
the number of bytes to read.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibStream.Seek(System.Int64,System.IO.SeekOrigin)
member.summary: Calling this method always throws a .

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibStream.SetLength(System.Int64)
member.summary: Calling this method always throws a .

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.Compress.Compressors.Deflate.ZlibStream.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Write data to the stream.

remarks.para: If you wish to use the ZlibStream to compress data while writing, you can create a ZlibStream with CompressionMode.Compress, and a writable output stream. Then call Write() on that ZlibStream, providing uncompressed data as input. The data sent to the output stream will be the compressed form of the data written. If you wish to use the ZlibStream to decompress data while writing, you can create a ZlibStream with CompressionMode.Decompress, and a writable output stream. Then call Write() on that stream, providing previously compressed data. The data sent to the output stream will be the decompressed form of the data written.
A ZlibStream can be used for Read() or Write(), but not both.

member.param: The buffer holding data to write to the stream.
the offset within that data array to find the first byte to write.
the number of bytes to write.

xor corresponding text input and round key input bytes

Mix the bytes of every column in a linear way

member.summary: Sends a SSH_MSG_CHANNEL_DATA message with the specified payload.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Channels.Channel.SendData(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sends a SSH_MSG_CHANNEL_DATA message with the specified payload.
member.param: An array of containing the payload to send.
The zero-based offset in at which to begin taking data from.
The number of bytes of to send.

remarks.para: When the size of the data to send exceeds the maximum packet size or the remote window size does not allow the full data to be sent, then this method will send the data in multiple chunks and will wait for the remote window size to be adjusted when it's zero.

This is done to support SSH servers will a small window size that do not agressively increase their window size. We need to take into account that there may be SSH servers that only increase their window size when it has reached zero.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Channels.ChannelSession.SendChannelOpenMessage
member.summary: Sends the channel open message.
member.exception: The size of the packet exceeds the maximum size defined by the protocol.

remarks.para: When a session semaphore for this instance has not yet been obtained by this or any other thread, the thread will block until such a semaphore is available and send a to the remote host.

Note that the session semaphore is released in any of the following cases:
A is received for the channel being opened.
The remote host does not respond to the within the configured .
The remote host closes the channel.
The is disposed.
A socket error occurs sending a message to the remote host.

If the session semaphore was already obtained for this instance (and not released), then this method immediately returns control to the caller. This should only happen when another thread has obtain the session semaphore and already sent the , but the remote host did not confirmed or rejected attempt to open the channel.

member.summary: Releases unmanaged and - optionally - managed resources
member.param: true to release both managed and unmanaged resources; false to release only unmanaged resources.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Channels.ChannelSession.ReleaseSemaphore
member.summary: Releases the session semaphore.
member.remarks: When the session semaphore has already been released, or was never obtained by this instance, then this method does nothing.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Channels.IChannel.SendData(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sends a SSH_MSG_CHANNEL_DATA message with the specified payload.
member.param: An array of containing the payload to send.
The zero-based offset in at which to begin taking data from.
The number of bytes of to send.

remarks.para: When the size of the data to send exceeds the maximum packet size or the remote window size does not allow the full data to be sent, then this method will send the data in multiple chunks and will wait for the remote window size to be adjusted when it's zero.

This is done to support SSH servers will a small window size that do not agressively increase their window size. We need to take into account that there may be SSH servers that only increase their window size when it has reached zero.

member.name: T:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Common.PipeStream
member.summary: PipeStream is a thread-safe read/write data stream for use between two threads in a single-producer/single-consumer type problem.
member.remarks: Update on 2008/10/9 1.1 - uses Monitor instead of Manual Reset events for more elegant synchronicity.

member.summary: Maximum number of bytes to store in the buffer.

member.summary: Setting this to true will cause Read() to block if it appears that it will run out of data.

member.summary: Indicates whether the current is disposed.

member.name: P:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Common.PipeStream.MaxBufferLength
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum number of bytes to store in the buffer.
member.value: The length of the max buffer.

member.name: P:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Common.PipeStream.BlockLastReadBuffer
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to block last read method before the buffer is empty. When true, Read() will block until it can fill the passed in buffer and count. When false, Read() will not block, returning all the available buffer data.
member.remarks: Setting to true will remove the possibility of ending a stream reader prematurely.
member.value: true if block last read method before the buffer is empty; otherwise, false.
member.exception: Methods were called after the stream was closed.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Common.PipeStream.Flush
member.summary: When overridden in a derived class, clears all buffers for this stream and causes any buffered data to be written to the underlying device.
member.exception: Methods were called after the stream was closed.
member.remarks: Once flushed, any subsequent read operations no longer block until requested bytes are available. Any write operation reactivates blocking reads.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Common.PipeStream.Seek(System.Int64,System.IO.SeekOrigin)
member.summary: When overridden in a derived class, sets the position within the current stream.
member.returns: The new position within the current stream.
member.param: A byte offset relative to the origin parameter.
A value of type indicating the reference point used to obtain the new position.
member.exception: The stream does not support seeking, such as if the stream is constructed from a pipe or console output.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Common.PipeStream.SetLength(System.Int64)
member.summary: When overridden in a derived class, sets the length of the current stream.
member.param: The desired length of the current stream in bytes.
member.exception: The stream does not support both writing and seeking, such as if the stream is constructed from a pipe or console output.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Common.PipeStream.Read(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: When overridden in a derived class, reads a sequence of bytes from the current stream and advances the position within the stream by the number of bytes read.
member.returns: The total number of bytes read into the buffer. This can be less than the number of bytes requested if that many bytes are not currently available, or zero if the stream is closed or end of the stream has been reached.
member.param: The zero-based byte offset in buffer at which to begin storing the data read from the current stream.
The maximum number of bytes to be read from the current stream.
An array of bytes. When this method returns, the buffer contains the specified byte array with the values between offset and (offset + count - 1) replaced by the bytes read from the current source.
member.exception: The sum of offset and count is larger than the buffer length.
Methods were called after the stream was closed.
The stream does not support reading.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Common.PipeStream.ReadAvailable(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns true if there are
member.returns: True if data available; otherwisefalse.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Common.PipeStream.Write(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: When overridden in a derived class, writes a sequence of bytes to the current stream and advances the current position within this stream by the number of bytes written.
member.param: The zero-based byte offset in buffer at which to begin copying bytes to the current stream.
The number of bytes to be written to the current stream.
An array of bytes. This method copies count bytes from buffer to the current stream.
member.exception: The stream does not support writing.
Methods were called after the stream was closed.
The sum of offset and count is greater than the buffer length.

member.name: T:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.ISftpClient
member.summary: Implementation of the SSH File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) over SSH.

member.name: P:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.ISftpClient.BufferSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum size of the buffer in bytes.
member.value: The size of the buffer. The default buffer size is 32768 bytes (32 KB).

remarks.para: For write operations, this limits the size of the payload for individual SSH_FXP_WRITE messages. The actual size is always capped at the maximum packet size supported by the peer (minus the size of protocol fields).

For read operations, this controls the size of the payload which is requested from the peer in a SSH_FXP_READ message. The peer will send the requested number of bytes in a SSH_FXP_DATA message, possibly split over multiple SSH_MSG_CHANNEL_DATA messages.
To optimize the size of the SSH packets sent by the peer, the actual requested size will take into account the size of the SSH_FXP_DATA protocol fields.
The size of the each indivual SSH_FXP_DATA message is limited to the local maximum packet size of the channel, which is set to 64 KB for SSH.NET. However, the peer can limit this even further.

member.exception: The method was called after the client was disposed.

remarks.para: The TERM environment variable contains an identifier for the text window's capabilities. You can get a detailed list of these cababilities by using the ‘infocmp’ command.
The column/row dimensions override the pixel dimensions(when nonzero). Pixel dimensions refer to the drawable area of the window.

member.name: T:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.PrivateKeyFile
member.summary: Represents private key information.

remarks.para:
The following private keys are supported:
RSA in OpenSSL PEM and ssh.com format
DSA in OpenSSL PEM and ssh.com format
ECDSA 256/384/521 in OpenSSL PEM format
ED25519 in OpenSSH key format

The following encryption algorithms are supported:
DES-EDE3-CBC
DES-EDE3-CFB
DES-CBC
AES-128-CBC
AES-192-CBC
AES-256-CBC

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.PrivateKeyFile.ParseOpenSshV1Key(System.Byte[],System.String)
member.summary: Parses an OpenSSH V1 key file (i.e. ED25519 key) according to the the key spec: https://github.com/openssh/openssh-portable/blob/master/PROTOCOL.key.

member.summary: Quotes a path in a way to be suitable to be used with a shell-based server.
member.returns: A quoted path.

remarks.para: If contains a single-quote, that character is embedded in quotation marks (eg. "'"). Sequences of single-quotes are grouped in a single pair of quotation marks.

An exclamation mark in is escaped with a backslash. This is necessary because C Shell interprets it as a meta-character for history substitution even when enclosed in single quotes or quotation marks.
All other characters are enclosed in single quotes. Sequences of such characters are grouped in a single pair of single quotes.

References:
Shell Command Language
Unix C-Shell special characters and their uses
Differences Between Bourne and C Shell Quoting

member.summary: Return a value indicating whether the specified path is a valid SCP file path.
member.returns: if is a valid SCP file path; otherwise, .
member.remarks:
To match OpenSSH behavior (introduced as a result of CVE-2018-20685), a file path is considered invalid in any of the following conditions:
is a zero-length string.
is ".".
is "..".
contains a forward slash (/).

Class representing a simple version of a big decimal. A SimpleBigDecimal is basically a {@link java.math.BigInteger BigInteger} with a few digits on the right of the decimal point. The number of (binary) digits on the right of the decimal point is called the scale of the SimpleBigDecimal. Unlike in {@link java.math.BigDecimal BigDecimal}, the scale is not adjusted automatically, but must be set manually. All SimpleBigDecimals taking part in the same arithmetic operation must have equal scale. The result of a multiplication of two SimpleBigDecimals returns a SimpleBigDecimal with double scale.

Class holding methods for point multiplication based on the window τ-adic nonadjacent form (WTNAF). The algorithms are based on the paper "Improved Algorithms for Arithmetic on Anomalous Binary Curves" by Jerome A. Solinas. The paper first appeared in the Proceedings of Crypto 1997.

The window width of WTNAF. The standard value of 4 is slightly less than optimal for running time, but keeps space requirements for precomputation low. For typical curves, a value of 5 or 6 results in a better running time. When changing this value, the αu's must be computed differently, see e.g. "Guide to Elliptic Curve Cryptography", Darrel Hankerson, Alfred Menezes, Scott Vanstone, Springer-Verlag New York Inc., 2004, p. 121-122
The αu's for a=0 as an array of ZTauElements.
The αu's for a=0 as an array of TNAFs.
The αu's for a=1 as an array of ZTauElements.
The αu's for a=1 as an array of TNAFs.
Class representing an element of Z[τ]. Let λ be an element of Z[τ]. Then λ is given as λ = u + vτ. The components u and v may be used directly, there are no accessor methods. Immutable class.
The "real" part of λ.
The "τ-adic" part of λ.

member.name: T:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Security.Org.BouncyCastle.Math.EC.ECCurve
member.remarks: Base class for an elliptic curve.

members.member:
Normalization ensures that any projective coordinate is 1, and therefore that the x, y coordinates reflect those of the equivalent point in an affine coordinate system. Where more than one point is to be normalized, this method will generally be more efficient than normalizing each point separately.
@param points An array of points that will be updated in place with their normalized versions, where necessary

Normalization ensures that any projective coordinate is 1, and therefore that the x, y coordinates reflect those of the equivalent point in an affine coordinate system. Where more than one point is to be normalized, this method will generally be more efficient than normalizing each point separately. An (optional) z-scaling factor can be applied; effectively each z coordinate is scaled by this value prior to normalization (but only one actual multiplication is needed).
@param points An array of points that will be updated in place with their normalized versions, where necessary @param off The start of the range of points to normalize @param len The length of the range of points to normalize @param iso The (optional) z-scaling factor - can be null
Create a cache-safe lookup table for the specified sequence of points. All the points MUST belong to this ECCurve instance, and MUST already be normalized.

Decode a point on this curve from its ASN.1 encoding. The different encodings are taken account of, including point compression for Fp (X9.62 s 4.2.1 pg 17). @return The decoded point.

member.name: T:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Security.Cryptography.BCrypt
member.summary: BCrypt implementation.

remarks.para: BCrypt implements OpenBSD-style Blowfish password hashing using the scheme described in "A Future- Adaptable Password Scheme" by Niels Provos and David Mazieres.

This password hashing system tries to thwart off-line password cracking using a computationally-intensive hashing algorithm, based on Bruce Schneier's Blowfish cipher. The work factor of the algorithm is parameterised, so it can be increased as computers get faster.
Usage is really simple. To hash a password for the first time, call the method with a random salt, like this:
To check whether a plaintext password matches one that has been hashed previously, use the method:
The method takes an optional parameter (workFactor) that determines the computational complexity of the hashing:
remarks.code: string strong_salt = BCrypt.GenerateSalt(10); string stronger_salt = BCrypt.GenerateSalt(12);
remarks.para: The amount of work increases exponentially (2^workFactor), so each increment is twice as much work. The default workFactor is 10, and the valid range is 4 to 31.

members.member: Define the fixed p0/p1 permutations used in keyed S-box lookup. By changing the following constant definitions, the S-boxes will automatically Get changed in the Twofish engine.
gSubKeys[] and gSBox[] are eventually used in the encryption and decryption methods.

Reed-Solomon code parameters: (12,8) reversible code:
G(x) = x^4 + (a+1/a)x^3 + ax^2 + (a+1/a)x + 1
where a = primitive root of field generator 0x14D

member.name: P:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Session.IsConnected
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the session is connected.
member.value: true if the session is connected; otherwise, false.
member.remarks:
This methods returns true in all but the following cases:
The is disposed.
The SSH_MSG_DISCONNECT message - which is used to disconnect from the server - has been sent.
The client has not been authenticated successfully.
The listener thread - which is used to receive messages from the server - has stopped.
The socket used to communicate with the server is no longer connected.

member.summary: Waits for the specified handle or the exception handle for the receive thread to signal within the connection timeout.
member.exception: A received package was invalid or failed the message integrity check.
None of the handles are signaled in time and the session is not disconnecting.
A socket error was signaled while receiving messages from the server.
member.remarks: When neither handles are signaled in time and the session is not closing, then the session is disconnected.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Session.IsSocketConnected
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether the socket is connected.
member.returns: true if the socket is connected; otherwise, false.

remarks.para: As a first check we verify whether is true. However, this only returns the state of the socket as of the last I/O operation.
Therefore we use the combination of with mode and to verify if the socket is still connected.
Conclusion: when the return value is true - but no data is available for reading - then the socket is no longer connected.
When a is used from multiple threads, there's a race condition between the invocation of and the moment when the value of is obtained. To workaround this issue we synchronize reads from the .

member.summary: Gets or sets the operation timeout.
member.value: The timeout to wait until an operation completes. The default value is negative one (-1) milliseconds, which indicates an infinite timeout period.
member.exception: The method was called after the client was disposed.
represents a value that is less than -1 or greater than milliseconds.

member.name: P:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.SftpClient.BufferSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the maximum size of the buffer in bytes.
member.value: The size of the buffer. The default buffer size is 32768 bytes (32 KB).

remarks.para: For write operations, this limits the size of the payload for individual SSH_FXP_WRITE messages. The actual size is always capped at the maximum packet size supported by the peer (minus the size of protocol fields).

For read operations, this controls the size of the payload which is requested from the peer in a SSH_FXP_READ message. The peer will send the requested number of bytes in a SSH_FXP_DATA message, possibly split over multiple SSH_MSG_CHANNEL_DATA messages.
To optimize the size of the SSH packets sent by the peer, the actual requested size will take into account the size of the SSH_FXP_DATA protocol fields.
The size of the each indivual SSH_FXP_DATA message is limited to the local maximum packet size of the channel, which is set to 64 KB for SSH.NET. However, the peer can limit this even further.

member.exception: The method was called after the client was disposed.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Sftp.SftpFileStream.Read(System.Byte[],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Reads a sequence of bytes from the current stream and advances the position within the stream by the number of bytes read.
member.param: An array of bytes. When this method returns, the buffer contains the specified byte array with the values between and ( + - 1) replaced by the bytes read from the current source.
The zero-based byte offset in at which to begin storing the data read from the current stream.
The maximum number of bytes to be read from the current stream.
member.returns: The total number of bytes read into the buffer. This can be less than the number of bytes requested if that many bytes are not currently available, or zero (0) if the end of the stream has been reached.
member.exception: The sum of and is larger than the buffer length.
The stream does not support reading.
Methods were called after the stream was closed.

remarks.para: This method attempts to read up to bytes. This either from the buffer, from the server (using one or more SSH_FXP_READ requests) or using a combination of both.
The read loop is interrupted when either bytes are read, the server returns zero bytes (EOF) or less bytes than the read buffer size.

When a server returns less number of bytes than the read buffer size, this may indicate that EOF has been reached. A subsequent (SSH_FXP_READ) server request is necessary to make sure EOF has effectively been reached. Breaking out of the read loop avoids reading from the server twice to determine EOF: once in the read loop, and once upon the next or invocation.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Sftp.SftpFileStream.ReadByte
member.summary: Reads a byte from the stream and advances the position within the stream by one byte, or returns -1 if at the end of the stream.
member.returns: The unsigned byte cast to an , or -1 if at the end of the stream.
member.exception: The stream does not support reading.
Methods were called after the stream was closed.

member.summary: Sets the position within the current stream.
member.param: A byte offset relative to the parameter.
A value of type indicating the reference point used to obtain the new position.
member.returns: The new position within the current stream.
member.exception: The stream does not support seeking, such as if the stream is constructed from a pipe or console output.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.Sftp.SftpFileStream.SetLength(System.Int64)
member.summary: Sets the length of the current stream.
member.param: The desired length of the current stream in bytes.
member.exception: The stream does not support both writing and seeking.
Methods were called after the stream was closed.

remarks.para: Buffers are first flushed.

If the specified value is less than the current length of the stream, the stream is truncated and - if the current position is greater than the new length - the current position is moved to the last byte of the stream.
If the given value is greater than the current length of the stream, the stream is expanded and the current position remains the same.

The handle did not get signaled within the specified timeout.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.SubsystemSession.WaitOne(System.Threading.WaitHandle,System.Int32)
member.summary: Blocks the current thread until the specified gets signaled, using a 32-bit signed integer to specify the time interval in milliseconds.
member.param: To number of milliseconds to wait for to get signaled, or -1 to wait indefinitely.
member.returns: true if received a signal within the specified timeout; otherwise, false.
member.exception: The connection was closed by the server.
member.remarks: The blocking wait is also interrupted when either the established channel is closed, the current session is disconnected or an unexpected occurred while processing a channel or session event.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.SubsystemSession.WaitAny(System.Threading.WaitHandle,System.Threading.WaitHandle,System.Int32)
member.summary: Blocks the current thread until the specified gets signaled, using a 32-bit signed integer to specify the time interval in milliseconds.
member.param: The first handle to wait for.
The second handle to wait for.
To number of milliseconds to wait for a to get signaled, or -1 to wait indefinitely.
member.returns: 0 if received a signal within the specified timeout, and 1 if received a signal within the specified timeout.
member.exception: The connection was closed by the server.
The handle did not get signaled within the specified timeout.

remarks.para: The blocking wait is also interrupted when either the established channel is closed, the current session is disconnected or an unexpected occurred while processing a channel or session event.
When both and are signaled during the call, then 0 is returned.

member.name: M:UnderAutomation.UniversalRobots.SSH.SubsystemSession.WaitAny(System.Threading.WaitHandle[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Waits for any of the elements in the specified array to receive a signal, using a 32-bit signed integer to specify the time interval.
member.param: A array - constructed using - containing the objects to wait for.
To number of milliseconds to wait for a to get signaled, or -1 to wait indefinitely.
member.returns: The array index of the first non-system object that satisfied the wait.
member.exception: The connection was closed by the server.
No object satified the wait and a time interval equivalent to has passed.
member.remarks: For the return value, the index of the first non-system object is considered to be zero.
